framework.framework_title: Writing an Introduction 2: social sciences and humanities

framework_intro.para:
Social science and humanities introductions often have a similar three-move structure to that of the natural sciences. However, there is more flexibility in the sequence of moves, and moves may overlap or be performed simultaneously. A wider range of steps is also found.
Here is a framework to help you write your introduction (after Swales and Feak, 2004). For the full reference, see References.
There are spaces for you to add the content of your introduction.

step.label: What is the purpose of the introduction?

commentary.para: The main purpose of an introduction is to situate research within its context, showing how it relates to other research in the field and/or to circumstances in the world.

It gives the examiners their first impression of your study and shows your knowledge of the research area. This helps them know what to expect and makes it easier for them to follow the rest of your work.

Social science and humanities introductions often have a similar three-move structure to that of natural sciences. However, the introduction is likely to be more discursive, with extended descriptions and examples to establish the context of the research. There is more flexibility in the sequence of moves, and moves may overlap or be performed simultaneously. A wider range of steps is also found (see ‘The structure in detail’ section).

Writers in these disciplines are often concerned with the stylistic effect of their text on their readers. The introduction may begin with a step designed to attract the reader's attention: it may give a relevant quotation, example or personal reason for interest in the topic, or present the purpose or contribution of the study first.
(After Swales and Feak, 2004)
The model text is an extract from an introduction to a research article in the ‘Journal of African Economies’. The study estimates the benefits and costs of improving the road network in Africa.
This introduction combines steps from both Move 1 and Move 3.
Sentence 1 presents the contribution of the research and attracts attention. This is a combination of Move 3 Step 8 and Move 1 Step 1.
The rest of the paragraph gives background information and describes an important world problem. This is Move 1 Steps 3 and 2.
This paragraph reviews the literature. This is Step 5 of Move 1.
Sentence 1 makes a summary statement about the literature so far.
Sentences 2 and 3 cite individual studies and give details of their findings.
Sentence 4 generalizes from the literature and claims that the area is important.
The writer quotes the literature for support.
This paragraph reviews the situation in the world. It uses Step 3 of Move 1.
Sentence 1 makes a generalization about programmes for addressing the problem.
Examples are then given.
The last sentence generalizes about the programmes and claims that they are important.
The writer refers to the literature to support the claim.
This paragraph situates the research in relation to previous work. It uses steps from Move 2 and Move 3.
Move 2: Establishing a niche
Sentence 1 raises a new question. (Step 3)
Moves 2 and 3: Establishing and occupying the niche
Sentence 2 presents the research as a continuation of previous work (Move 2 Step 4) and gives the method ('by developing …') (Move 3 Step 5)
The last part of the paragraph indicates how this study differs from previous research approaches. (Move 3 Step 5)
This paragraph explains the organization of the paper. It uses Step 9 of Move 3.
The paragraph gives details of the contents of each section in turn.
The present tense is often used in the introduction.
The present perfect tense is used to look back over a recent time period and to summarize what has been done so far in the literature or in the world.
Different ways of describing the organization and contents of your dissertation.
Different ways of referring to the literature.

checklist.point: Social science and humanities introductions often have a similar three-move structure to that of natural sciences. However, the introduction is likely to be more discursive, with extended descriptions and examples to establish the context of the research. There is more flexibility in the sequence of moves. A wider range of steps is also found.
You can use the three-move structure to help you write your introduction.
In a long dissertation, you may need to situate your research in relation to several different areas. To do this, repeat the cycle of moves and steps as often as necessary.
The Introduction is often the last chapter or section to be written.
Organize the points you want to make into the framework.
Have I attracted the reader's attention at the beginning?
Have I used present and present perfect tenses appropriately?
Have I used different ways to describe the organization and contents of my dissertation?
Have I used different ways of referring to the literature?
Have I quoted and referenced my sources accurately?
Have I checked vocabulary, grammar, spelling and punctuation?

paragraph.name: Writing an Introduction 2: social sciences and humanities
paragraph.desc: How to write an effective introduction to your work
paragraph.tip: TIP The three-move structure will help you to write your introduction, but there is a great deal of flexibility in the sequence of moves. They may overlap or be performed simultaneously.

paragraph.name: Paragraph 1: Introduction
paragraph.desc: Attracts attention to your research and gives background information.
paragraph.tip: TIP This is where you start to establish your research territory (Move 1) by attracting the reader's attention (Step 1).

content.para: This paper presents evidence on the trade expansion potential of improvements in Sub-Saharan Africa's road network.At present, overland transport is so difficult and costly that Africa's diverse regions remain largely isolated from one another. Overland trade between the large urban centres of West Africa and South Africa is almost non-existent. …

This paperpresents evidence on the trade expansion potential of improvements in Sub-Saharan Africa's road network. At present, overland transportis so difficult and costly that Africa's diverse regionsremain largely isolated from one another. Overland trade between the large urban centres of West Africa and South Africais almost non-existent. …

paragraph.name: Paragraph 2
paragraph.desc:
Reviews the literature.
Move 1: Establishing a territory
Steps
1. Attract the reader's attention and interest, e.g. with a relevant example or quotation.
2. Describe why your general study area is relevant or important in research and/or the world.
3. Make generalizations about your area; give background information or examples. Each generalization becomes narrower until you focus on your own specific topic.
4. Define terms, especially when there is no agreement in the field.
5. Review previous research.
paragraph.tip: TIP Continue establishing your research territory (Move 1) by looking at the literature (Step 5).

para.extra_info: Numerous empirical studies have examined the economic impact of poor road conditions (see, e.g., Henderson et al., 2001, for a review).

Amjadi and Yeats (1995) find that the relatively low level of Sub-Saharan African exports is essentially due to high transport costs. In a study of transport costs and trade, Limao and Venables (2001) find that poor infrastructure accounts for 60% of transport costs for landlocked countries, as opposed to 40% for coastal countries.
Improving cross-border infrastructure is therefore an important part of the development agenda in Africa:

‘The vision and ultimate objective for Africa should be to create a single market of 750 million people that is competitive within itself and within the global economy. A critical pre-requisite to this is regional infrastructure integration across Africa.’ (Simuyemba, 2000, p.3).

paragraph.name: Paragraph 3
paragraph.desc: Reviews the situation in the world.
paragraph.tip: TIP Continue establishing your research territory (Move 1) by making a generalization (Step 3).

content.para: The World Bank and the African Development Bank (ADB) have both launched initiatives to encourage more integrated infrastructure development. The [World] Bank's Sub-Saharan Africa Transport Policy Program (SSATP) has focused on … The ADB has proposed … Such programmes could give a significant boost to regional integration efforts on the continent (Deichmann and Gill, 2008; Naudé, 2009).

paragraph.name: Paragraph 4
paragraph.desc:
Situates the research in relation to previous work.
Move 2: Establishing a niche
Steps
1. Indicate a gap, problem or need in previous research.
2. Indicate a problem or need in the world.
3. Raise a new question to be answered.
4. Continue or extend the work of other researchers.
paragraph.tip: TIP This is where you establish your particular niche (Move 2) by, for example, raising a new question (Step 3) and presenting your work as a continuation of previous work (Step 4).

content.para: How much difference would an integrated, functional road network make for African development? This paper extends the previously cited work by developing an analytical framework for quantifying the benefits and costs of continental road network upgrading.In contrast to the trade literature on the topic discussed in what follows, we estimate the costs as well as trade benefits of transport improvements and we base our analysis on geographically explicit modelling of a realistic trans-African transport network. In contrast to project cost-benefit analysis or engineering studies, we estimate the continent-wide economic benefits from transport improvements, rather than focusing on local benefits alone, which are often measured as traffic volume increases or imputed time savings.

paragraph.name: Paragraph 5
paragraph.desc:
Describes the organization of the paper.
Move 3: Occupying the niche
Steps
1. Present your research and state its purpose, aims or objectives.
2. State your research questions or hypotheses.
3. State your theoretical position.
4. Set out the parameters of your research.
5. Describe briefly your methods and participants in survey research.
6. Outline your argument.
7. Give brief details of your findings or a model you propose.
8. Justify your research by showing the significance or contribution of your study.
9. Describe the organization of your dissertation.
paragraph.tip: TIP This is where you occupy your research niche (Move 3) by, for example, detailing your research aims (Step 1), your research questions (Step 2) and/or your study methods (Step 5), and/or describing the organization of your paper (Step 9).

content.para:
The remainder of the paper is organised as follows.Section 2 reviews the theoretical and empirical literature on gravity models, highlighting evidence on overland trade flows in developing countries.In Section 3, we identify a network of primary roads connecting all 42 mainland Sub-Saharan capitals ...Section 4 estimates a gravity model for Sub-Saharan Africa … We use the results to estimate current trade flows in the inter-city network and to simulate the impact of a major improvement in road network quality.We then explore the implications of our results for trade expansion at the regional, country and city levels.In Section 5, we estimate the costs of network improvement, using a World Bank database ...Section 6 concludes the paper.
(Buys et al., 2010) For the full reference, see References.
